stem: For each client, determine the appropriate triage category based on the provided assessment data. Select one triage category for each client.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
07:15 RN S. Park reporting from on-site triage at mass casualty incident (MCI) following a building collapse. Approximately 30+ individuals involved. Resources are stretched; need immediate physician orders for efficient triage.

Client A: ~40-year-old male, RR 36 and labored, SpO2 88% on RA, significant chest trauma. 

Client B: ~60-year-old female, fractured femur, in severe pain, but vitals stable. 

Client C: ~25-year-old male, minor lacerations, able to ambulate, appears anxious.

Client D: ~70-year-old male, no pulse, no respirations, massive head trauma. Pupils fixed and dilated.

Client E: ~30-year-old female, open abdominal wound with evisceration, RR 28, BP 90/60, appears confused.

Need immediate directives to facilitate appropriate triage tagging per START protocol. Awaiting your orders. S. Park, RN.

tabs.title: Lab Results
tabs.content: No lab data available at this time due to the emergent nature of the mass casualty incident and on-site triage conditions.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
Client A: Chest trauma, labored breathing, cyanosis noted around lips.
Client B: Obvious deformity of right femur, guarding the injured area.
Client C: Multiple superficial lacerations on arms and face. Ambulatory.
Client D: Massive head trauma. No response to stimuli. Pupils fixed and dilated.
Client E: Open abdominal wound with evisceration. Pale and diaphoretic.

rows.text: Client A: 40-year-old male, RR 36, SpO2 88% on room air, chest trauma.
Client B: 60-year-old female, fractured femur, severe pain, stable vitals.
Client C: 25-year-old male, minor lacerations, ambulatory, anxious.

rationale.correct:
In START triage, patients are categorized based on the severity of their condition and the likelihood of survival with immediate intervention. 

RED (Immediate): These patients require immediate intervention to save their lives. They typically have compromised airway, breathing, or circulation. 

YELLOW (Delayed): These patients have serious injuries but are not in immediate danger of death. They require medical attention but can wait a short period of time.

GREEN (Minor): These patients have minor injuries and are able to walk. They can wait for medical attention.

BLACK (Expectant): These patients are unlikely to survive given available resources. They may have devastating injuries and little chance of survival.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect triage categorization can lead to inappropriate allocation of resources, potentially compromising patient outcomes. Misclassifying a critical patient as lower priority could delay necessary interventions, while prioritizing less critical patients could strain resources needed for those in immediate danger.

answerBreakdown.text: Client A: 40-year-old male, RR 36, SpO2 88% on room air, chest trauma.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Client A exhibits signs of respiratory distress and hypoxia, necessitating immediate intervention to improve oxygenation and ventilation. High RR, low SpO2, and chest trauma indicate a critical respiratory issue.

answerBreakdown.text: Client B: 60-year-old female, fractured femur, severe pain, stable vitals.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Client B has a significant injury (fractured femur) causing severe pain. However, her vital signs are stable. While she requires medical attention, she can wait a short period of time.

answerBreakdown.text: Client C: 25-year-old male, minor lacerations, ambulatory, anxious.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Client C has minor injuries and is able to ambulate, classifying him as GREEN. He can wait for medical attention.

answerBreakdown.text: Client D: 70-year-old male, no pulse, no respirations, massive head trauma.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Client D shows no signs of life and has sustained massive head trauma, indicating minimal chance of survival with available resources. He is classified as BLACK.

answerBreakdown.text: Client E: 30-year-old female, open abdominal wound with evisceration, RR 28, BP 90/60, confused.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Client E has an open abdominal wound with evisceration, elevated respiratory rate, hypotension, and altered mental status. These signs indicate severe internal injuries and shock, requiring immediate intervention to stabilize her condition.

clinicalPearls: Remember the START triage acronym: Simple Triage And Rapid Treatment.
Assess the ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation) first when triaging patients.
The ability to follow simple commands indicates the patient is not in immediate danger.

questionTrap.trap: Students often misclassify patients with stable vital signs despite significant injuries as RED, overlooking the need to prioritize those with compromised ABCs.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the immediate threats to life (airway, breathing, circulation) when triaging. Stable vitals, even with significant injuries, allow for a slightly delayed intervention.

mnemonic.title: START Triage Mnemonic
mnemonic.expansion: RPM: Respiration, Perfusion, Mental Status. Use these to rapidly assess and categorize patients during triage.
